articles.headline: Consider the Worst Case With Zipcar
articles.snippet: Zipcar caps the liability insurance coverage it provides for members at $300,000 per incident, which could leave drivers involved in an accident exposed to an expensive lawsuit.
articles.abstract: Zipcar caps the liability insurance coverage it provides for members at $300,000 per incident, which could leave drivers involved in an accident exposed to an expensive lawsuit.
articles.lead_paragraph: People who have driven Zipcars or listened to one of the company’s 560,000 or so customers wax rhapsodic over the wonders of car-sharing know that Zipcar is a rare kind of for-profit company.

articles.headline: Labor Board Case Against Boeing Points to Fights to Come
articles.snippet: The federal labor board has sought to reinterpret and more vigorously enforce the rules governing employers and employees.
articles.abstract: The federal labor board has sought to reinterpret and more vigorously enforce the rules governing employers and employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: For businesses, it was the type of action they have feared from a National Labor Relations Board dominated by Democrats. For labor unions, it was the type of action they have hoped for. And for both, it may be a sign of things to come.

articles.headline: Camouflaging Price Creep
articles.snippet: Retailers are trying to figure out the pressure points in rising prices. Will people pay more for jeans, but not T-shirts?
articles.abstract: Retailers are trying to figure out the pressure points in rising prices. Will people pay more for jeans, but not T-shirts?
articles.lead_paragraph: The Easter special at many retailers this year involves higher price tags.

articles.headline: Amazon’s Trouble Raises Cloud Computing Doubts
articles.snippet: Companies are expected to reassess backup and recovery after the interruption at Amazon Web Services.
articles.abstract: Companies are expected to reassess backup and recovery after the interruption at Amazon Web Services.
articles.lead_paragraph: As technical problems interrupted computer services provided by Amazon for a second day on Friday, industry analysts said the troubles would prompt many companies to reconsider relying on remote computers beyond their control.

articles.headline: Royal Wedding Wine May Be Bubbly and English
articles.snippet: The once-absurd notion of fine English wine is becoming a more common one, with some wondering whether sparkling wine will replace Champagne at the royal wedding.
articles.abstract: The once-absurd notion of fine English wine is becoming a more common one, with some wondering whether sparkling wine will replace Champagne at the royal wedding.
articles.lead_paragraph: DITCHLING, England — In January, Michel Roux Jr., a London chef who is on the tasting committee that recommends wines to be served by the royal family, made a suggestion that would have been unthinkable not long ago. Wouldn’t it be nice, Mr. Roux asked a reporter for The Telegraph, if at the wedding reception for Prince William and Kate Middleton the glasses were filled not with Champagne but with English sparkling wine?

articles.headline: Builders of New Homes Seeing No Sign of Recovery
articles.snippet: Sales of new single-family homes in February were down more than 80 percent from the 2005 peak, signaling a shift in behavior from buyers seeking smaller places.
articles.abstract: Sales of new single-family homes in February were down more than 80 percent from the 2005 peak, signaling a shift in behavior from buyers seeking smaller places.
articles.lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Ill. — In this distant Chicago suburb, a builder has finally found a way to persuade people to buy a new house: he throws in a car.

articles.headline: BBC, Under Criticism, Struggles to Tighten Its Belt
articles.snippet: The BBC, the world’s biggest and oldest public broadcasting company, has effectively sentenced itself to a 16 percent budget cut through 2017.
articles.abstract: The BBC, the world’s biggest and oldest public broadcasting company, has effectively sentenced itself to a 16 percent budget cut through 2017.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON
articles.byline: By Sarah Lyall and Eric Pfanner

articles.headline: Scenes From the Madoff Masquerade
articles.snippet: Bernard L. Madoff remained calm and seemingly in control as the financial crisis closed in around him, a new book says.
articles.abstract: Bernard L. Madoff remained calm and seemingly in control as the financial crisis closed in around him, a new book says.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was adapted from “The Wizard of Lies: Bernie Madoff and the Death of Trust,” by Diana B. Henriques, a reporter for The New York Times. The book, to be published on Tuesday by Times Books, analyzes Mr. Madoff’s rise and fall.

articles.headline: A Crack in Wall Street’s Defenses
articles.snippet: In a case involving Citigroup’s Smith Barney unit, arbitrators say the financial crisis can’t be blamed for all losses.
articles.abstract: In a case involving Citigroup’s Smith Barney unit, arbitrators say the financial crisis can’t be blamed for all losses.
articles.lead_paragraph: TWO individual investors just scored a remarkable win against Citigroup.

articles.headline: President of Yemen Offers to Leave, With Conditions
articles.snippet: Ali Abdullah Saleh agreed to cede power if certain conditions were met, including immunity for him and his family.
articles.abstract: Ali Abdullah Saleh agreed to cede power if certain conditions were met, including immunity for him and his family.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Yemen’s embattled president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, said Saturday that he accepted a proposal by Arab mediators that would shift power to his deputy 30 days from the signing of a formal agreement and grant him and his family, who occupy key positions in Yemen’s security apparatus, immunity from prosecution.

articles.headline: Exiles Shaping World’s Image of Syria Revolt
articles.snippet: A self-styled vanguard abroad is ferrying out images and news that are anarchic and illuminating, if incomplete.
articles.abstract: A self-styled vanguard abroad is ferrying out images and news that are anarchic and illuminating, if incomplete.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — On the bloodiest day of Syria’s uprising, Rami Nakhle’s fingers drifted over the keyboard in a room silent but for the news bulletins of Al Jazeera, yet filled with the commotion on his computer screen.

articles.headline: Haitians Forced Out of Tents to Homes Just as Precarious
articles.snippet: More than half of the Haitians driven into camps by the 2010 earthquake have moved out, but most of them appear to have been forced out or to have left to escape crime and living conditions.
articles.abstract: More than half of the Haitians driven into camps by the 2010 earthquake have moved out, but most of them appear to have been forced out or to have left to escape crime and living conditions.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — The way Robert Darvin sees it, he is one of the lucky ones.

articles.headline: Stimulus by Fed Is Disappointing, Economists Say
articles.snippet: The Fed must decide whether to continue buying bonds in an effort to revive the economy, even though the recovery has flagged since the government began a $600 billion program in November.
articles.abstract: The Fed must decide whether to continue buying bonds in an effort to revive the economy, even though the recovery has flagged since the government began a $600 billion program in November.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve’s experimental effort to spur a recovery by purchasing vast quantities of federal debt has pumped up the stock market, reduced the cost of American exports and allowed companies to borrow money at lower interest rates.

articles.headline: Lawmakers Seek to Unclog Road to Confirmation
articles.snippet: Lawmakers in both parties are moving to cut the number of administration posts subject to Senate approval.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers in both parties are moving to cut the number of administration posts subject to Senate approval.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hoping to unclog the Senate and spare scores of presidential appointees from what is often a grueling confirmation process, leading lawmakers in both parties are moving to cut the number of administration posts that are subject to Senate approval.

articles.headline: Google, a Giant in Mobile Search, Seeks New Ways to Make It Pay
articles.snippet: The search giant is throwing its power and data at problems specific to mobile phones, like translating phone calls on the fly.
articles.abstract: The search giant is throwing its power and data at problems specific to mobile phones, like translating phone calls on the fly.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — In early 2008, in the early days of the iPhone era, Google engineers began noticing something unusual in the search engine’s logs. Owners of these new phones were doing a huge number of Web searches.

articles.headline: Classified Files Offer New Insights Into Detainees
articles.snippet: Classified assessments of detainees at Guantánamo Bay prison obtained by The Times give the fullest public picture to date of the prisoners held there.
articles.abstract: Classified assessments of detainees at Guantánamo Bay prison obtained by The Times give the fullest public picture to date of the prisoners held there.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A trove of more than 700 classified military documents provides new and detailed accounts of the men who have done time at the Guantánamo Bay prison in Cuba, and offers new insight into the evidence against the 172 men still locked up there.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage, William Glaberson and Andrew W. Lehren

articles.headline: Judging Detainees’ Risk, Often With Flawed Evidence
articles.snippet: Analysts sometimes released detainees wrongly judged a minimal threat and held others who were no threat.
articles.abstract: Analysts sometimes released detainees wrongly judged a minimal threat and held others who were no threat.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Benjamin Weiser

articles.headline: U.S. Networks Add Britons to Royal Wedding Coverage
articles.snippet: Since every network will share the same camera feeds of the royal wedding on Friday, competition has been fierce for on-air talent to make coverage stand out.
articles.abstract: Since every network will share the same camera feeds of the royal wedding on Friday, competition has been fierce for on-air talent to make coverage stand out.
articles.lead_paragraph: In November, when the “save the date” was circulated for Prince William and Kate Middleton’s wedding, Elena Nachmanoff immediately booked a trip to London. She was going shopping — for royalty experts.

articles.headline: Syrian Crisis Tests the Mettle of Its Autocratic Ruler
articles.snippet: Bashar al-Assad, who has long encouraged hopes for a less repressive Syria and then dashed those hopes, is at a decisive moment.
articles.abstract: Bashar al-Assad, who has long encouraged hopes for a less repressive Syria and then dashed those hopes, is at a decisive moment.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — For years, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria has nourished a reputation as a youthful and forward-looking leader in a region full of aging autocrats, a man who might yet reform the repressive police state he inherited from his father, given time and opportunity.

articles.headline: War, in Life and Death
articles.snippet: Tim Hetherington and Chris Hondros, who were killed last week covering the fighting in Libya, used their cameras to communicate the human suffering of war.
articles.abstract: Tim Hetherington and Chris Hondros, who were killed last week covering the fighting in Libya, used their cameras to communicate the human suffering of war.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tim Hetherington was a war photographer in every regard. Tall, brutally handsome and modest, he had a British accent plucked from a Graham Greene novel and the body fat of a Diet Coke.

articles.headline: One Size Fits Nobody: Seeking a Steady 4 or a 10
articles.snippet: With no standard sizes for women’s clothing from one store to the next, a handful of companies are tackling the problem of finding the right fit.
articles.abstract: With no standard sizes for women’s clothing from one store to the next, a handful of companies are tackling the problem of finding the right fit.
articles.lead_paragraph: In one store, you’re a Size 4, in another a Size 8, and in another a Size 10 — all without gaining an ounce.

articles.headline: A Fight Over How Drugs Are Pitched
articles.snippet: Marketing to doctors using prescription records bearing their names is an increasingly contentious practice, with three states enacting laws to limit the uses of the records for marketing.
articles.abstract: Marketing to doctors using prescription records bearing their names is an increasingly contentious practice, with three states enacting laws to limit the uses of the records for marketing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before pharmaceutical company marketers call on a doctor, they do their homework. These salespeople typically pore over electronic profiles bought from data brokers, dossiers that detail the brands and amounts of drugs a particular doctor has prescribed. It is a marketing practice that some health care professionals have come to hate.

articles.headline: DVRs Give More Shows a Lifeline
articles.snippet: Networks see that more people are watching their shows with a lag on DVRs, and feel those numbers should be counted as well. Advertisers are less convinced.
articles.abstract: Networks see that more people are watching their shows with a lag on DVRs, and feel those numbers should be counted as well. Advertisers are less convinced.
articles.lead_paragraph: The digital video recorder was supposed to lay waste to network television. Instead the playback device is offering some shows a lifeline — so much so that network programmers now factor in ratings a full week after a show’s scheduled appearance.

articles.headline: Taliban Breach Afghan Prison; Hundreds Free
articles.snippet: The Taliban staged a bold prison break in Afghanistan, freeing nearly 500 prisoners, officials said.
articles.abstract: The Taliban staged a bold prison break in Afghanistan, freeing nearly 500 prisoners, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — Taliban leaders carried out an audacious plot on Monday to free nearly 500 fighters from southern Afghanistan’s largest prison, leading them through a tunnel dug over more than five months and equipped with electricity and air pipes, which suggested that the insurgents remained formidable and wily opponents despite recent setbacks.
articles.byline: By Taimoor Shah and Alissa J. Rubin

articles.headline: Syria Escalates Crackdown as Tanks Go to Restive City
articles.snippet: The army deployed tanks in Dara’a on Monday, according to accounts by human rights activists, who said that at least 25 people had been killed.
articles.abstract: The army deployed tanks in Dara’a on Monday, according to accounts by human rights activists, who said that at least 25 people had been killed.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian Army stormed the restive city of Dara’a with tanks and soldiers and helped detain dozens in towns across the country Monday in an escalation of the crackdown on Syria’s five-week-old uprising, according to residents and human rights activists. They said at least 25 people had been killed in Dara’a, with reports of bodies strewn in the streets.
